reviews.title: Incredibly buggy, often unusable
reviews.text: The New Yorker is a catastrophically flawed app. It is often demoralizing and humiliating to consider that I pay $200 a year for a subscription to this nearly unusable service. It is plagued with a seemingly endless onslaught of annoying bugs - most consistently, whenever you close the app, it exits the article and does not save your place so you have to then find the article again and then find your place to take up where you left off. It also decides to sign you out of your account at least twice a week and force you to go through the bureaucratic horrors of logging in again (extra fun when you are on a plane or other places without cell service). Then there are lots of exciting little bugs that whimsically appear and disappear. Most recently, every article just turned into a blank, empty endless scroll with no words after about three sentences. It might be a conflict of interest but I do think the psychology of what keeps us coming back to this awful experience would be a great subject for Jia Tolentino‘s next piece.

reviews.title: The app really needs work

Signs itself out randomly and makes it impossible to sign back  picture don’t align with the article titles in the list of articles in “current issue” I search short fiction then select a story and I get a completely random article. Repeatedly. Did someone hire his old college friend’s god son to develop this? I quit the app last year because the app was (hint not sap, not pap, but cr…yeah. (And there is a bit too much shallow pop culture stuff these days). But I missed it so in our modern wilderness and resubscribed this year. Still…. The app. The app! Onward and upward..
I hope!

reviews.title: i love the new yorker
reviews.text:
but this app is so glitchy!

my biggest problem is the search function, which doesn’t turn up results based on relevance. example: say i search the name “jane doe” - it seems the programming will search for “jane” and “doe” instead of “jane doe” and then the search results are sorted by date instead of relevance, and inundated with any mention of “jane” or “doe”, and the “jane doe” i’m looking for is totally buried. 

for others frustrated by this, i’ve come up with a slightly more effective workaround: i search only the most specific word that i think is related to what i’m trying to find. like if i know the jane doe article is about spelunking i just search “spelunking” and hope for the best. otherwise i just google “jane doe new yorker” and immediately find what i’m looking for, try to open the article in the app, the app is glitchy and can’t open it for me. 

oh but how i do love reading the new yorker

analyzed.title: Incredibly buggy, often unusable
analyzed.text: The New Yorker is a catastrophically flawed app. It is often demoralizing and humiliating to consider that I pay $200 a year for a subscription to this nearly unusable service. It is plagued with a seemingly endless onslaught of annoying bugs - most consistently, whenever you close the app, it exits the article and does not save your place so you have to then find the article again and then find your place to take up where you left off. It also decides to sign you out of your account at least twice a week and force you to go through the bureaucratic horrors of logging in again (extra fun when you are on a plane or other places without cell service). Then there are lots of exciting little bugs that whimsically appear and disappear. Most recently, every article just turned into a blank, empty endless scroll with no words after about three sentences. It might be a conflict of interest but I do think the psychology of what keeps us coming back to this awful experience would be a great subject for Jia Tolentino‘s next piece.

reviews.title: Inept Developers
reviews.text:
The app itself is antiquated compared to apps from WaPo, NYT, or LeMonde. 

But what’s worse is that for over a year, if you hit the listen button on an article and leave your phone on a counter. 9 times out of 10 it will crash the app within a minute. It’s been over a year of this happening.

Other news apps if you click the listen button, you get a working app that will let you listen to the article all the way through even when your phone enters sleep. It then will go to the next article automatically.

And then you have the bright workers at the WSJ. We get a voice that reads the news like an automated operator from the 90s. But have no fear, won’t have to listen to it for long since the app will most likely crash.

I can understand an unfair comparison to WaPo as it was acquired by Bezos and he’d be able to leverage talented individuals for the app. But the NYT? Why does this app perform like a potato next to them as well.

Every time there’s an update, I hope that day will be the day I can listen to the morning news. 

And every time I get proved an idiot for thinking the clowns at the WSJ are competent.

Context: I have the current phone. On current software.

reviews.title: The surrender of the WSJ
reviews.text:
The Wall Street Journal was once the gold standard of American business journalism. Today, it reads like a parody of its former self. Facts have given way to partisan talking points, with coverage increasingly indistinguishable from Democratic Party messaging and the fashionable dogmas of socialist, secular elites. Editorial honor is gone. Rigor is gone. In its place are shallow, unverified hit pieces aimed not at informing readers, but at harming Trump, Religious, children and scolding the country that built it.

I say this with real sadness. I have read this paper for nearly forty years, and watching its steady abandonment of intellectual honesty, economic literacy, and even basic respect for its readers has been painful. What was once a mighty institution now seems content to trade credibility for applause from people who would have mocked it a generation ago. The Wall Street Journal didn’t lose the battle —it surrendered.   (Maybe it is the Neville Chamberlain of papers)
reviews.author: Business Men Buy Papers

reviews.title: Wsj app make my phone HOT!
reviews.text:
iPhone 15 Pro running iOS 18.7.  Phone immediately heats up when using the WSJ app….. no other app causes this.  WSJ app can easily consume 30% of my battery with just a single casual reading session.       
**** Update Oct 4,’25. After the recent WSJ app update (14.50.0) 34197 it seems like the high battery consumption and burning hot phone has been improved…..WSJ still consumes a lot of battery but less than before….App still hangs periodically then just gets itself “unstuck”
**** Update Oct 7 ‘25.  I am now on iOS 18.7.1. App is now worse than ever…. Hangs frequently and now I have to force close the app.  There are now also video based Ads that cannot be paused.
****Update Oct 20, 2025.. Updated to 14.51.0 with no improvement.

**Update Nov 15 ‘25. Big backslide with the 14.53.0 release! My phone gets really warm again and WsJ is again consuming tons of battery. Has used 21% of my battery in about 20 minutes of reading

*** Update Dec 20 ‘25. Now at iOS 26.2 and WSJ 14.56.00…. Phone gets hotter than ever! WSJ seemed to have fixed the hot battery issue only to break it again….

WSJ….. turn off this auto-play garbage!! 

WSJ Developer…. It would be nice if your release notes told users what was fixed rather than “…. Fixed minor issues”.

It seems that no one is reading or responding to feedback on the app here. I’m going to try reaching out to the editors via email…. Someone at WSJ needs to know how awful the app is and how upset customers are.

reviews.title: STOP the Auto-Play Videos and Ads!
reviews.text:
PLEASE provide an ability to stop auto-playing videos in the app (which I access mainly from an iPad). It is annoying and distracting. I pull up an article to READ it - not to be assaulted by a barrage of audio and video. 

Same for the auto-playing video ads. They are tacky and make the app look and feel like a third world bazaar. 

Navigation remains clunky, with some navigation at bottom of page and some at top. No other app I’ve seen uses this mixed method of navigation

There is a lot of “jerkiness”, especially looking at sections of articles, where the list spontaneously moves up or down for unknown reasons (I suspect it’s ads or surveillance of users). The app also crashes frequently. 

All in all, the app is very weak and frustrating. I find myself enjoying the content, but cursing the app, every time I bring up the WSJ on my iPad

reviews.title: Great reporting, bad app
reviews.text:
I really love the news reporting here, but the app’s performance has been a major hurdle, especially after the recent update. There are several critical UX issues:

- Scroll Instability: The story list jumps randomly while scrolling, which is incredibly frustrating.

- Audio/Video Conflict: While listening to audio transcripts, the jumping scroll often triggers a video auto-play. This mutes the current audio - a significant issue while driving.

- Syncing Issues: Bookmarking is unreliable. The "Bookmarked" tab often displays incorrect stories or fails to update unless I restart the app or toggle tabs. Bookmarking/unbookmarking actions often don't work.

- Stability: The app crashes sometimes.

I’d love to keep using this for my daily news, but the technical execution needs serious attention to be usable.
reviews.author: lucas676

reviews.title: Ugh! - where is today’s WsJ
reviews.text:
Can’t share via iMessage anymore.  I can’t take all the video!  Let me turn it off.  If it’s worth watching I will.


Super glitchy…. When is today’s edition going to drop.   This app gets worse with each release.  Turn off all the video.  If I wan to watch, I will.  If I wanted a video news channel, I would have the WSJ.





After many months of this new app version, and repeated updates, it continues to be an inferior experience to the prior version.

For each item an update attempts to address, another feature or functionality is broken or lost.  When are we going to have the ability to read the print version while offline again?  When will I be able to load the current print version without having to launch the app, close and launch again (often 3 or 4 times), waiting for 20 or 30 seconds each time to see if it will work?

The developer response to the overwhelming frustration with the version launched last summer and the persistent promises of improvement suggest no one on the development team is capable of creating and improving this horrible product.  This app should have been kept in development until you figured out how to make it work.
reviews.author: Blkfish71

reviews.title: Doesn’t open anymore
reviews.text:
The digital version on the WSJ used to be a pleasure to use. The months long “improvement” process has resulted in significant slowing of the app as well as bizarre relocations of search functions back and forth across the page. Now, it simply won’t work. I have deleted and reinstalled the app but it remains nonfunctional. Fortunately, I still have the traditional newspaper. Addendum: so the app now works again but still has very frustrating features. For example, when it opens, it displays the previous day’s edition, not the current one. Second, it remains very slow to open page 1 (tho possibly not AS slow as it was). Articles are opening more consistently-previously, you could try to open an article and it would just freeze-that seems better. Fact remains, what was a smooth running, reliable and pleasurable experience has been significantly degraded. They keep talking about “improving” the product but if they were serious, they would go back to square one.

Addendum:
They’re at it again, fiddling with the app and making it extremely frustrating to use-it freezes, cuts out and slows to a crawl. After reboots, shut downs and restarts it reverts to the older version of the app which works flawlessly. You think there’s a lesson in that? Very disappointing.

reviews.title: Uses too much storage
reviews.text:
This app is 
 flawed for several reasons that the developers should be able to fix: 1. The app runs hot and drains the battery more than any other app on my iPhone. 2. The app uses 2GB+ of storage even when there are no saved articles — and there is no way to clear the cache (the only way to remedy the issue is to delete the app periodically). 3. Every time you navigate to another app (e.g. Safari), the WSJ reloads and you lose the article you’re reading and where you are in the article. This last one is especially egregious because Apple has a standard way for applications to be coded to “hold their place” when you navigate to another iOS app. For reference, I have plenty of storage and memory on my iPhone and this problem only occurs with the WSJ app.

analyzed.title: Inept Developers
analyzed.text:
The app itself is antiquated compared to apps from WaPo, NYT, or LeMonde. 

But what’s worse is that for over a year, if you hit the listen button on an article and leave your phone on a counter. 9 times out of 10 it will crash the app within a minute. It’s been over a year of this happening.

Other news apps if you click the listen button, you get a working app that will let you listen to the article all the way through even when your phone enters sleep. It then will go to the next article automatically.

And then you have the bright workers at the WSJ. We get a voice that reads the news like an automated operator from the 90s. But have no fear, won’t have to listen to it for long since the app will most likely crash.

I can understand an unfair comparison to WaPo as it was acquired by Bezos and he’d be able to leverage talented individuals for the app. But the NYT? Why does this app perform like a potato next to them as well.

Every time there’s an update, I hope that day will be the day I can listen to the morning news. 

And every time I get proved an idiot for thinking the clowns at the WSJ are competent.

Context: I have the current phone. On current software.

analyzed.title: The surrender of the WSJ
analyzed.text:
The Wall Street Journal was once the gold standard of American business journalism. Today, it reads like a parody of its former self. Facts have given way to partisan talking points, with coverage increasingly indistinguishable from Democratic Party messaging and the fashionable dogmas of socialist, secular elites. Editorial honor is gone. Rigor is gone. In its place are shallow, unverified hit pieces aimed not at informing readers, but at harming Trump, Religious, children and scolding the country that built it.

I say this with real sadness. I have read this paper for nearly forty years, and watching its steady abandonment of intellectual honesty, economic literacy, and even basic respect for its readers has been painful. What was once a mighty institution now seems content to trade credibility for applause from people who would have mocked it a generation ago. The Wall Street Journal didn’t lose the battle —it surrendered.   (Maybe it is the Neville Chamberlain of papers)
analyzed.author: Business Men Buy Papers
analyzed.summary: The reviewer expresses deep disappointment over the Wall Street Journal's perceived decline in editorial integrity, increased partisan bias, and loss of credibility compared to its former standards.

analyzed.author: * Patricio *
analyzed.summary: The user is frustrated with the app's frequent crashes and the need to restart it often.

analyzed.title: 40$ a month
analyzed.text: Why would anyone pay $40 a month for the news in the age of technology. Most I’d pay is 10$
analyzed.author: Anonymous199375
analyzed.summary: User complains that the $40 monthly subscription price is too high and suggests a maximum of $10.

analyzed.title: Why no comments?
analyzed.text: Obviously this is a very good newspaper, and I enjoy reading it. However, the app would be greatly improved by also allowing me to see the comments left by other readers on the article.
analyzed.author: jgsihdkxkhckgsidkhzir
analyzed.summary: User enjoys the newspaper but requests the addition of a comment section to view other readers' comments.

analyzed.title: Mark your one year
analyzed.text: If you don’t cancel your subscription, they will charge 43$ per month. A real shame.
analyzed.author: Proppppp
analyzed.summary: User complains about being charged $43 monthly due to unclear subscription cancellation process.

analyzed.title: Great content, but drains battery
analyzed.text: I find the content and writing is top-notch, the app UI is intuitive and easy to use, catering to those who prefer both blog style with most recent news appearing at top as well as broadsheet like the print edition. Another plus: the ads are low-key unlike other news apps. Starting a few months ago though I’ve noticed the WSJ app seriously drains my battery. I’d give it 5 stars if it wasn’t so power-hungry.
analyzed.author: JohnnyBravo77
analyzed.summary: The user praises the app's content, UI, and low-key ads but complains about significant battery drain.

analyzed.title: A 200-Year-Old Paper With a 2-Month-Old App
analyzed.text: Running the WSJ app on an iPhone 17 Pro Max feels like beta-testing a two-month-old startup, not using a product from a nearly 200-year-old institution. Perhaps the app team could take a few notes from Johanna Stern and set “basic performance” as a New Year’s resolution for 2026.
analyzed.author: NeoTX35
analyzed.summary: The WSJ app on iPhone 17 Pro Max delivers a poor and unstable performance, resembling a beta product rather than a mature app from a longstanding institution.

analyzed.title: Where are the comments?
analyzed.text: Excellent app and some of the only real journalism left out there. Would give 5 stars easily if the comments below articles were not missing.
analyzed.author: missMyAndroidSoMuch
analyzed.summary: User praises the app's journalism quality but requests the addition of comments below articles.

analyzed.title: Just Add WSJ.com to Home Screen Instead
analyzed.text:
The app eats my battery like no other app and makes my phone hot. The scrolling seems to be pretty jumpy and unpredictable lately.

I’ve ended up adding the WSJ.com webpage to my Home Screen and having it “Open as a web app”. Boom, problems solved!
analyzed.author: CougarGrad
analyzed.summary: The app causes excessive battery drain, device overheating, and erratic scrolling behavior, leading the user to switch to the web app version.

analyzed.title: Wsj app make my phone HOT!
analyzed.text:
iPhone 15 Pro running iOS 18.7.  Phone immediately heats up when using the WSJ app….. no other app causes this.  WSJ app can easily consume 30% of my battery with just a single casual reading session.       
**** Update Oct 4,’25. After the recent WSJ app update (14.50.0) 34197 it seems like the high battery consumption and burning hot phone has been improved…..WSJ still consumes a lot of battery but less than before….App still hangs periodically then just gets itself “unstuck”
**** Update Oct 7 ‘25.  I am now on iOS 18.7.1. App is now worse than ever…. Hangs frequently and now I have to force close the app.  There are now also video based Ads that cannot be paused.
****Update Oct 20, 2025.. Updated to 14.51.0 with no improvement.

**Update Nov 15 ‘25. Big backslide with the 14.53.0 release! My phone gets really warm again and WsJ is again consuming tons of battery. Has used 21% of my battery in about 20 minutes of reading

*** Update Dec 20 ‘25. Now at iOS 26.2 and WSJ 14.56.00…. Phone gets hotter than ever! WSJ seemed to have fixed the hot battery issue only to break it again….

WSJ….. turn off this auto-play garbage!! 

WSJ Developer…. It would be nice if your release notes told users what was fixed rather than “…. Fixed minor issues”.

It seems that no one is reading or responding to feedback on the app here. I’m going to try reaching out to the editors via email…. Someone at WSJ needs to know how awful the app is and how upset customers are.
analyzed.author: Disappointed S40 user
analyzed.summary: The WSJ app causes significant battery drain and phone overheating, frequently hangs, includes unpausable video ads, and lacks transparent release notes, with poor responsiveness to user feedback.

analyzed.title: STOP the Auto-Play Videos and Ads!
analyzed.text:
PLEASE provide an ability to stop auto-playing videos in the app (which I access mainly from an iPad). It is annoying and distracting. I pull up an article to READ it - not to be assaulted by a barrage of audio and video. 

Same for the auto-playing video ads. They are tacky and make the app look and feel like a third world bazaar. 

Navigation remains clunky, with some navigation at bottom of page and some at top. No other app I’ve seen uses this mixed method of navigation

There is a lot of “jerkiness”, especially looking at sections of articles, where the list spontaneously moves up or down for unknown reasons (I suspect it’s ads or surveillance of users). The app also crashes frequently. 

All in all, the app is very weak and frustrating. I find myself enjoying the content, but cursing the app, every time I bring up the WSJ on my iPad
analyzed.author: NJ Guitarist
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated by auto-playing videos and ads, inconsistent navigation, jerky article lists, and frequent crashes, making the app difficult to use on iPad despite enjoying the content.

analyzed.title: Trash
analyzed.text: If you want to read more on an. Article you need to pay up homie lol
analyzed.author: Eduardo82000
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated by the requirement to pay to read the full article.

analyzed.title: Great newspaper, terrible app
analyzed.text: I love the WSJ paper. But the app is terrible. I want a newspaper, not videos. I certainly don’t want autoplaying videos every time I open the app. And either there’s no way to turn them off or the setting is hidden in a way that makes it impossible to find.
analyzed.author: RW_DC
analyzed.summary: User dislikes autoplaying videos in the app and finds it difficult or impossible to disable them, preferring a traditional newspaper experience.

analyzed.title: Glitchy and constantly fails
analyzed.text: When reading headlines, the app jumps around constantly. Compared to every other news app I use, this one is notoriously glitchy. Often I open it and it just freezes. Disappointing given this is the content I want.
analyzed.author: DillMcGill
analyzed.summary: The app frequently jumps around when reading headlines and often freezes on opening, leading to a frustrating user experience.

analyzed.title: Great reporting, bad app
analyzed.text:
I really love the news reporting here, but the app’s performance has been a major hurdle, especially after the recent update. There are several critical UX issues:

- Scroll Instability: The story list jumps randomly while scrolling, which is incredibly frustrating.

- Audio/Video Conflict: While listening to audio transcripts, the jumping scroll often triggers a video auto-play. This mutes the current audio - a significant issue while driving.

- Syncing Issues: Bookmarking is unreliable. The "Bookmarked" tab often displays incorrect stories or fails to update unless I restart the app or toggle tabs. Bookmarking/unbookmarking actions often don't work.

- Stability: The app crashes sometimes.

I’d love to keep using this for my daily news, but the technical execution needs serious attention to be usable.
analyzed.author: lucas676
analyzed.summary: The user praises the news content but reports major technical issues including scroll instability, audio-video conflicts, unreliable bookmarking, and app crashes, severely impacting usability.

analyzed.title: Ugh! - where is today’s WsJ
analyzed.text:
Can’t share via iMessage anymore.  I can’t take all the video!  Let me turn it off.  If it’s worth watching I will.


Super glitchy…. When is today’s edition going to drop.   This app gets worse with each release.  Turn off all the video.  If I wan to watch, I will.  If I wanted a video news channel, I would have the WSJ.





After many months of this new app version, and repeated updates, it continues to be an inferior experience to the prior version.

For each item an update attempts to address, another feature or functionality is broken or lost.  When are we going to have the ability to read the print version while offline again?  When will I be able to load the current print version without having to launch the app, close and launch again (often 3 or 4 times), waiting for 20 or 30 seconds each time to see if it will work?

The developer response to the overwhelming frustration with the version launched last summer and the persistent promises of improvement suggest no one on the development team is capable of creating and improving this horrible product.  This app should have been kept in development until you figured out how to make it work.
analyzed.author: Blkfish71
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated with the app's excessive video content, glitches, slow loading, loss of offline print version, and poor developer responsiveness, leading to a worsening experience compared to prior versions.

analyzed.title: Doesn’t open anymore
analyzed.text:
The digital version on the WSJ used to be a pleasure to use. The months long “improvement” process has resulted in significant slowing of the app as well as bizarre relocations of search functions back and forth across the page. Now, it simply won’t work. I have deleted and reinstalled the app but it remains nonfunctional. Fortunately, I still have the traditional newspaper. Addendum: so the app now works again but still has very frustrating features. For example, when it opens, it displays the previous day’s edition, not the current one. Second, it remains very slow to open page 1 (tho possibly not AS slow as it was). Articles are opening more consistently-previously, you could try to open an article and it would just freeze-that seems better. Fact remains, what was a smooth running, reliable and pleasurable experience has been significantly degraded. They keep talking about “improving” the product but if they were serious, they would go back to square one.

Addendum:
They’re at it again, fiddling with the app and making it extremely frustrating to use-it freezes, cuts out and slows to a crawl. After reboots, shut downs and restarts it reverts to the older version of the app which works flawlessly. You think there’s a lesson in that? Very disappointing.
analyzed.author: jcm43md
analyzed.summary: The app has become significantly slower, unstable, and frustrating to use after recent updates, with issues including freezing, crashes, slow loading, and confusing UI changes.

analyzed.title: Too Many Notifications!
analyzed.text: Can we please control what type of notifications we get? I want breaking news. I have no interest in some random article. I read the whole thing almost daily. I don’t need encouragement.
analyzed.author: Thandrol
analyzed.summary: User requests the ability to customize notification types to receive only breaking news and avoid irrelevant articles.

analyzed.title: Ads in a paid sub
analyzed.text: You gotta be kidding me. I pay a subscription and you add ads!
analyzed.author: mpls55412
analyzed.summary: User is upset about ads appearing despite paying for a subscription.

analyzed.title: Jittery scrolling!
analyzed.text: This app jitters when scrolling and then the phone heats up. Annoying to use the app. The New York Times app behaves properly. I gave 3 stars because the reporting and writing are excellent.
analyzed.author: Murray130
analyzed.summary: The app experiences jittery scrolling and causes the phone to overheat, making it annoying to use despite good content quality.

analyzed.title: Gets stuck scrolling
analyzed.text: App worked fine before but now it gets stuck while scrolling, difficult to read articles without the app hanging and sometimes needing to be reset. Need to fix this bug!
analyzed.author: Rav4 prime 99
analyzed.summary: User reports the app frequently hangs and gets stuck during scrolling, requiring resets to continue reading.

analyzed.title: Buggy App
analyzed.text: I like the WSJ, but the app needs some work. When I open the app, it takes a while to update the latest news. I have to sit there staring at the old news until it finally reloads. It will also glitch while I’m scrolling through the main feed, where it suddenly shifts way down. Then it takes me a while to go back and find the article I was going to click on.
analyzed.author: Brett_123
analyzed.summary: The app experiences slow updates of the latest news and glitches during scrolling, causing a poor user experience.

analyzed.title: It used to seem more balanced
analyzed.text: Sadly, Media is a uniparty now and that includes the WSJ.
analyzed.author: musoyui
analyzed.summary: The user expresses dissatisfaction with perceived media bias, including the Wall Street Journal.

analyzed.title: Missing two key features
analyzed.text: Doesn’t integrate with iOS and Google well. Opening stories in Google News and elsewhere should allow me to open the story in the app where I’m logged in. And I really miss audio speed control. Please allow us to set playback speed!
analyzed.author: p7345
analyzed.summary: User requests better integration with iOS and Google News and the addition of audio playback speed control.

analyzed.title: Uses too much storage
analyzed.text:
This app is 
 flawed for several reasons that the developers should be able to fix: 1. The app runs hot and drains the battery more than any other app on my iPhone. 2. The app uses 2GB+ of storage even when there are no saved articles — and there is no way to clear the cache (the only way to remedy the issue is to delete the app periodically). 3. Every time you navigate to another app (e.g. Safari), the WSJ reloads and you lose the article you’re reading and where you are in the article. This last one is especially egregious because Apple has a standard way for applications to be coded to “hold their place” when you navigate to another iOS app. For reference, I have plenty of storage and memory on my iPhone and this problem only occurs with the WSJ app.
analyzed.author: GEO444NE
analyzed.summary: The app suffers from high battery and storage usage, lacks cache clearing, and fails to maintain reading position when switching apps, leading to a poor user experience.

analyzed.title: App crashes on every use
analyzed.text: What a happened to app stability?? It not hangs or crashes on every use!
analyzed.author: BeatHappy
analyzed.summary: User reports frequent app hangs and crashes, indicating poor app stability.

analyzed.title: SLOW Please fix backend!
analyzed.text:
The newspaper is great! But the app is the most inefficient, slow, computationally hungry app on the App Store! 

Please work on your backend, the ui is fine. It makes the app unusable and drains battery quickly.
analyzed.author: Somebody3012
analyzed.summary: The user praises the newspaper content but complains about the app's poor performance and high battery usage, making it inefficient and unusable.

analyzed.title: Freezing while scrolling since recent updates
analyzed.text: Since the last update, the app freezes while scrolling. Previously it seemed to preload content allowing for even offline reading. The previous architecture was better and never froze.
analyzed.author: Rachel BK
analyzed.summary: The latest update causes the app to freeze during scrolling and has removed the previous offline reading functionality, indicating a regression in performance and architecture.

analyzed.title: Frog in a pot
analyzed.text: Feeling like a frog in a pot. WSJ app keeps getting worse. Distracting videos, ads, bad updates.  Par for the course. We never jump out even while paying $500 a year!  Such ingenious profiteers they are….
analyzed.author: Artcubed
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated with distracting videos, excessive ads, poor updates, and high subscription cost in the WSJ app.

analyzed.title: Drains battery amazingly fast
analyzed.text: Although I like the app, when using it my phone gets hot to the touch and the app chews through the battery amazingly quickly.  Not sure if this is a design feature or a bug.
analyzed.author: Hughbill
analyzed.summary: User reports the app causes significant battery drain and device overheating, impacting usability.

analyzed.title: Huge performance issue
analyzed.text: Ever since the newer version of this app came out, I have had non stop lags and pauses.  It is just pulling text from the internet so I don't understand why this app is suddenly now so slow.  Obviously it is doing some sync or whatever but it still doesn't excuse this - none of the other apps that are very intense have this issue.
analyzed.author: WSJ reader digit
analyzed.summary: User experiences continuous lag and pauses after the latest app update, suspecting inefficient syncing causing slow performance compared to other apps.

analyzed.title: Good app but widgets would make it 5 star
analyzed.text: No complaints with the app but would like to see the WSJ widget come back.
analyzed.author: TheAvo-mountains
analyzed.summary: User requests the return of the WSJ widget, indicating a desire for this feature to be reinstated.

analyzed.title: Clunker
analyzed.text: Super clunky, slow app. News is obv good or would be 1 star
analyzed.author: miles Nardi
analyzed.summary: The user finds the app clunky and slow, negatively impacting their experience despite appreciating the news content.

analyzed.title: The UI got worse?
analyzed.text: Navigation is ungainly, but at least it’s painfully slow at (many) times
analyzed.author: pgaston
analyzed.summary: The user finds the navigation ungainly and often painfully slow, indicating poor usability and performance issues.

analyzed.title: App has been buggy for weeks
analyzed.text: The app seems to freeze constantly - mostly when you’re scrolling past video. It’s often jittery and laggy at times too.
analyzed.author: RajRD13
analyzed.summary: The app frequently freezes and exhibits jittery, laggy behavior, especially when scrolling past videos.

analyzed.title: Paid through December 5th – stopped working in October
analyzed.text: Will not allow me to access news I paid for. Apple/ WSJ say the subscription goes through December 5 –  I’ve been locked out of access since October. Demanding a new subscription: $349 for nine months of news.
analyzed.author: Total dish
analyzed.summary: User is locked out of paid news content despite active subscription, facing incorrect subscription status and being asked to pay again.

analyzed.title: Great content, but but app itself leaves a lot to be desired
analyzed.text: Great content, but the application has so many little things that I’m not thought through especially lately. It’s being a buggy hanging and experience has gone down.
analyzed.author: Hat3rik
analyzed.summary: The user appreciates the content but is frustrated by frequent bugs, app hanging, and a declining user experience.

analyzed.title: Spy App
analyzed.text: Uses your mic to provide ads even without permission!
analyzed.author: Chrishaas61
analyzed.summary: User complains about the app using the microphone to deliver ads without obtaining permission.

analyzed.title: Like the app, want speed control on audio
analyzed.text: The app is great minus one feature I really really want. Include faster audio speaking. Up to 3x minimum
analyzed.author: BotanyRulz
analyzed.summary: User praises the app but requests a faster audio speaking speed, ideally up to 3x.

analyzed.title: Great content, not great app
analyzed.text: Great content - I read it every day, but the app becomes more and more glitchy, freezes, and eventually crashes the more you use it 20-30 minutes). This is infuriating for full priced subscription to WSJ.
analyzed.author: Roman Todd
analyzed.summary: User appreciates the content but is frustrated by frequent app freezes, glitches, and crashes during use, especially given the full-priced subscription.

analyzed.title: 14.50.0 followed authors bug
analyzed.text: Grey mode is not dark mode, bring back true dark mode
analyzed.author: nenejdidi8374
analyzed.summary: User complains that the current grey mode is not a true dark mode and requests the return of a proper dark mode.

analyzed.title: Poor app design, but great news coverage
analyzed.text: The wsj news coverage is great, but the app keeps getting worse. It used to display many stories at once but now only shows about one at a time requiring unnecessary scrolling. I don’t care if they change the default look, but should give users a way to go back to the old format if they want.
analyzed.author: Brian1234456
analyzed.summary: The app's news display has been reduced to showing fewer stories at once, causing excessive scrolling, and lacks an option to revert to the previous layout.

analyzed.title: Freezes up while scrolling
analyzed.text: Been going on for weeks.  Latest update did not fix.
analyzed.author: kjmlam9
analyzed.summary: User reports a persistent problem that remains unresolved despite the latest update.

analyzed.title: Buggy, freezes
analyzed.text: This latest update causes the app to freeze.   I wish I could go back.
analyzed.author: Irritated.
analyzed.summary: The latest update causes the app to freeze, leading to user dissatisfaction.

analyzed.title: Stop the videos
analyzed.text: I find the embedded videos to be distracting and have been unable to turn them off. If I wanted to watch the news, I would turn on the TV. I read the Wall Street Journal because I don’t want to turn on the TV.
analyzed.author: Chip Oidos
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated by distracting embedded videos in the app and the inability to disable them.

analyzed.title: Good content; awful app
analyzed.text:
Three things. 
One, the app freezes whenever I scroll. I suspect it’s because it’s loading as content or videos. 
Two , give me an option to prevent videos from autoplaying. I don’t want to watch your videos; I want to read the articles. This isn’t some Buzzfeed and I’m not a child. Don’t treat me like one. 
Three, push notifications for breaking news also send feature article notifications. These are categorizing separately in notifications settings but not distinguished in execution.
analyzed.author: Dee Awr
analyzed.summary: The user experiences app freezing during scrolling, requests an option to disable video autoplay, and reports issues with push notifications not distinguishing breaking news from feature articles.

analyzed.title: Going the wrong way
analyzed.text:
Navigation that plays hide and seek. Videos that want to play, but don’t start at the beginning when you tap unmute. And lowbrow ads, despite me accepting all cookies and clicking on the good ones. This is not curated. 
I accept that I’m a bit old-school, but this is not beauty in the objective sense of the word. I downloaded this app in 2011. It’s not ascending. 
I love the reporting, but this app keeps getting worse.
analyzed.author: karlbruno
analyzed.summary: User complains about navigation problems, video playback issues, inappropriate ads, lack of content curation, and overall app quality decline despite liking the reporting feature.

analyzed.title: Freeze while scrolling
analyzed.text: The app has been freezing up when scrolling down. It’s been going on for months and seems getting worse. Not having similar issues with other news apps
analyzed.author: speedlimit89
analyzed.summary: The app frequently freezes during scrolling, an issue persisting and worsening over months, unlike other news apps.

analyzed.title: Update made my WSJ app more readable
analyzed.text: Live the update, it is more readable and clean , the new fonts are great to read for long time. Also the way live updates shows up for markets and economics and stocks is nicely displayed in Home Screen. Great work WSJ.
analyzed.author: Imharry4u
analyzed.summary: The user appreciates the improved readability, new fonts, and the well-displayed live updates on the Home Screen.

analyzed.title: Glitchy for the Price
analyzed.text: Reducing stars to 1 as the developers have not resolved the lagginess/glitches that have been highlighted by many users for several months. The app frequently glitches, doesn’t scroll and gets “stuck” on certain articles. Really not the sort of experience you would expect from a respectable news agency, especially not for the price that WSJ asks for.
analyzed.author: Zespeboy
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated with persistent lagging, glitches, and freezing issues in the app, leading to a poor experience despite the app's premium price.

analyzed.title: Laggy freezing app
analyzed.text: I got the app for the content, but I hate the interface. I don't know why you can't smooth scroll through a story.
analyzed.author: Whynothanks
analyzed.summary: User dislikes the app's interface and requests smooth scrolling through stories.

analyzed.title: My Favorite News Source
analyzed.text: An array of fascinating articles. I read it almost every morning.
analyzed.author: Bourke Design
analyzed.summary: User enjoys the app's interesting articles and uses it regularly every morning.

analyzed.title: Fix the bugs
analyzed.text: Latest app version is freezing up while scrolling
analyzed.author: bbdeeznutz
analyzed.summary: The latest app version freezes during scrolling, causing usability issues.

analyzed.title: Great news. App has been laggy
analyzed.text: Since the most recent update, what used to be a flawless app now constantly freezes and sometimes crashes. Can’t make it through a story with some glitch anymore.
analyzed.author: Lafargatron
analyzed.summary: The latest update has introduced frequent freezing and crashing, disrupting story playback.

analyzed.title: Keeps freezing
analyzed.text: App is ruined and keeps freezing while I am trying to read articles
analyzed.author: Adamb.12
analyzed.summary: The app frequently freezes during article reading, severely impacting usability.

analyzed.title: Crash and burn

analyzed.summary: The app frequently crashes, rendering it unusable, and lacks Apple CarPlay integration.

analyzed.title: locks / freezes
analyzed.text: constantly locks up while scrolling
analyzed.author: XXxft
analyzed.summary: The app frequently locks up during scrolling, causing usability issues.

analyzed.title: Like it
analyzed.text: Terrible app, a change from the prior one. In their efforts to restrict usage to one subscriber they made the app impossible to use. It increasingly stalls after the first few screens even though I am the only user. All attempts to reach help or technical support are useless. They never return emails or calls. Good paper but awful app and service.
analyzed.author: Bnbmn
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated with the app's restrictive single-subscriber usage, frequent stalls, and unresponsive customer support.

analyzed.title: great journalism, bad app
analyzed.text: I read the Print Edition every day in the app, and I have noticed a steady degradation of user experience. The large amount of embedded videos (some advertising, mostly WSJ content) autoplay and rapidly drain my iPad’s battery. Since there is no option to turn off autoplay, the only way to use the app for an extended period of time is with my wifi connection turned off. I don’t have the same issue with other apps (Economist, FT, books).
analyzed.author: Geoffrey Wildanger
analyzed.summary: User experiences battery drain due to autoplay videos in the app and requests an option to disable autoplay for better usability.

analyzed.title: Hard to believe how bad this app is
analyzed.text: This app is unusable and unfixable… might just go ahead and cancel my subscription.. and it does not work on any device, any platform.
analyzed.author: MP00004
analyzed.summary: User finds the app unusable and unfixable across all devices and platforms, considering subscription cancellation.

analyzed.title: Laggy performance
analyzed.text: Scrolling through a list of headlines shouldn’t cause the most recent iPhone to experience lag. You need to optimize your app better.
analyzed.author: EricLangston357
analyzed.summary: The user reports performance lag on the latest iPhone, indicating the app needs better optimization.

analyzed.title: App freezes when opening

1. I click a link from the 10-point email
2. I land on article in app
3. I can scroll briefly then app is unresponsive

Seems to happen more severely if I haven’t opened the app in a while.

analyzed.title: Slow, Buggy, non-responsive

analyzed.summary: User loves the journal feature but experiences frequent and severe app lagging, impacting usability.

analyzed.title: Pinging

analyzed.summary: User experiences persistent pinging notifications while reading articles, requiring app termination to stop.

analyzed.title: App Crashing
analyzed.text: App continues to be very buggy even after crashing issue has been resolved. The main feed constantly freezes making it impossible to use the app.  The fact that ads and media features seem to move everything around at random times is frustrating.
analyzed.author: History fan12
analyzed.summary: The app remains buggy with frequent freezing of the main feed and disruptive ads and media features affecting usability.

analyzed.title: Crashing even after multiple updates

analyzed.author: Rengaram
analyzed.summary: The app's page never loads and multiple updates have failed to fix this issue, leading to a very poor experience on iPhone 16 Pro.

analyzed.title: Scrolling is aweful
analyzed.text: Your news is great, but you’ve got a serious problem with the scrolling in this app that’s making it exceedingly difficult to read the daily news headlines.    I have to imagine others have noticed this, hope you can fix in the next update.
analyzed.author: Co9-bos
analyzed.summary: User praises the news content but reports serious scrolling issues that hinder reading headlines.

analyzed.title: Ads are locking up app
analyzed.text: Lately the app is freezing when trying to serve me ads. Makes me grumpy, because I pay you, you show me ads anyway, and they break your app.
analyzed.author: OpossibleKingdom
analyzed.summary: The app frequently freezes when displaying ads, causing user frustration especially since the user is paying for the service.

analyzed.title: App too glitchy
analyzed.text: I love reading the Wall Street Journal, but more frequently not when I open the app it freezes and does not allow me to scroll. Or it crashes. I have an up-to-date Apple iPhone and in 2025. I am disappointed that the app does not perform better.
analyzed.author: pointcg
analyzed.summary: User experiences frequent app freezes and crashes, leading to poor performance on an up-to-date iPhone.

analyzed.title: Needs work

But the app could use some serious improvement—it should offer dark mode and audio options for way more (if not all) stories. Lastly, when you share a story the only option is to use one of your gift links. There should be an option to just share the link.

I wish some of the writers could be my friends. They seem like nice people.

However, Brooks goes way beyond any sort of defense of capitalism - - and does so correctly in my view. “Character is destiny.”

reviews.title: The Rule of Law must stand!
reviews.text:
Thank you Atlantic! My spirits were lifted this morning as I read the article by Judge Wolf! 
How powerful can one person be? We are a country of laws. 
Today is the time to act on that idea! Judge Wolf tells us simply his plight and his dedication to the RULE OF LAW! 
We cannot be silent! 
I am convinced the power of WE the People can be tidal way of freedom. 
Our elections in 2026 give us the opportunity to unite and speak loudly about our sinking democracy! A tsunami must come! People, young and old, must vote and defend voting rights! 
I talk to everyone about my concerns for our freedom and the democracy that we must defend at all costs. 
Thank you Judge Wolf.

reviews.title: Great content. Bad app
reviews.text:
I love the journalism of the Atlantic but the app is pretty bad. First of all, to view articles you have to be a paid subscriber, if I’m paying I don’t want to see ads. Either offer two tier of subscriptions, a cheaper one with ads and a more expensive one without, or get rid of them entirely. 

The ads also aren’t incorporated into the app well. The content loads before the ads so you’ll begin reading and then the ads will finish loading and will scroll your view. Very annoying. 

But most annoying of all, 75% of the time I enter an article, the content will disappear from the page after around 10 seconds of being in the article. The only thing to do is leave the article and reenter. Though most of the time it will only disappear again requiring you to repeat the process.

reviews.author: $$$$the mag

reviews.title: Complicit, corrupt coverage
reviews.text:
I once loved this magazine, but it has strayed far from its abolitionist roots. When the "Israel Gaza Conflict" is reported on, this sorry excuse for a magazine unapologetically declares that 40,000 Palestinian lives are worth less than 4 Israeli hostages. And it continues to situate the colonial project of the Israeli state as the victim when every single reputable Human Rights organization has declared it a genocide (including those based in Israel). The NYT used to provide a "both sides" perspective on the lynching of Black Americans in 20th century, The Atlantic has shamelessly carried this abominable torch into the 21st century.

And this is just a single issue; the money they make from their obvious duplicity must be truly extraordinary.

This entire publication disgusts me. I am a high school social studies teacher and this publication is everything that is wrong with this world. It is an insult to the very idea of journalism and humanity. It may not be in this lifetime, but these cowards will one day be known for their evil.
reviews.author: mattygeebs

reviews.title: Brilliance!
reviews.text: Concise! Engaging!
reviews.author: brooksmahogany

reviews.title: Barely an app
reviews.text:
Not commenting on the journalism, this is an app review. 
This app could be so much better, right now it’s barely better than the website. Atlantic links don’t automatically open in the app. There’s no “read later” button for article links within the app that are shown throughout the article you’re reading so they just get lost. There are ads throughout every article even though only paying subscribers are able to read them. This is basic stuff that any decent subscription-based news/reading app should offer. 
I’d also like to be able to follow authors to be notified when they have new pieces available but considering the state of the app we’re not even close to little extras like that. I love reading the Atlantic — please make this app better, it would be so easy.

analyzed.title: Access problem
analyzed.text: When I am able to access the articles, they are really well written and enjoyable, but for some reason every time I enter, I have to reload the app and many times it asked me to sign up again, but I already have a subscription.
analyzed.author: Music Arranger
analyzed.summary: User experiences frequent app reloads and repeated sign-up prompts despite having a subscription, though content quality is appreciated.

analyzed.title: All It Needs Is a Widget
analyzed.text: Other than that, it’s perfect.
analyzed.author: Jeff Karren
analyzed.summary: The user expresses overall satisfaction, indicating the app is perfect aside from unspecified minor issues.

analyzed.title: Embedded ads are annoying
analyzed.text: If you’re paying for this, it should be ad-free, FULL STOP.
analyzed.author: Qazwdxedcrt
analyzed.summary: User complains about ads appearing in the paid version, expecting it to be ad-free.

analyzed.title: Log on
analyzed.text: I just wish the Atlantic could tell it’s me and let me see every article without fading away in 3rd paragraph and making me log in!
analyzed.author: Hicks26.2
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated by the app not recognizing them, limiting article visibility, and requiring login after partial reading.

analyzed.title: Great writing
analyzed.text: As a subscriber of the NY Times, the WSJ, and the Economist, I didn’t think I needed another subscription, but the Atlantic has great writing and content. It’s now my favorite reading source.
analyzed.author: MBV 05
analyzed.summary: The user appreciates the Atlantic's great writing and content, making it their favorite reading source despite existing subscriptions.

analyzed.title: One of the Best
analyzed.text: By far one of the most well written and tech-friendly news apps in the world. I mean that. Real news is a necessity for our ‘advanced’ society. Be different, read real news articles! In fact, you can even listen to many of them, too!!!
analyzed.author: Mr. Danite
analyzed.summary: The user highly praises the app for its well-written, tech-friendly news content and the availability of audio articles.

analyzed.title: The Atlantic
analyzed.text: Love the articles but even more the fact they are written at a high level of language.  When so much in our society is watered down it is refreshing to find reading that is a challenge to the mind.
analyzed.author: Bob TA
analyzed.summary: The user appreciates the high-level language and challenging content of the articles, finding it refreshing compared to simpler material.

analyzed.title: Atlantic articles
analyzed.text: I love the in-depth analysis.
analyzed.author: Golfkim@50
analyzed.summary: User appreciates the in-depth analysis feature of the app.

analyzed.title: My Thoughts about The Atlantic
analyzed.text: the best there is at everything it does
analyzed.author: PDX Jim
analyzed.summary: The user highly praises the app, stating it excels at all its functions.

analyzed.title: Aphorisms
analyzed.text: What an eye opening article to give a trajectory into the New Year . Thank You 💕
analyzed.author: Jim Forgette
analyzed.summary: The user expresses gratitude and appreciation for the insightful article providing a positive outlook for the New Year.

analyzed.title: In depth reporting
analyzed.text: I love your science reporting and the long article articles about things I didn’t know I was interested in. So grateful there is still genuine journalism in our country.
analyzed.author: dog society
analyzed.summary: User appreciates the quality and depth of the science reporting and long-form articles, valuing genuine journalism.

analyzed.title: Read the Atlantic!
analyzed.text: I subscribe to many news sources, but this is my favorite.
analyzed.author: almfish
analyzed.summary: User expresses strong preference for this news app over others.

analyzed.title: The app offers a terrible reading experience and no offline reading capability
analyzed.text: I find it uncomfortable to read on the app: specifically the formatting around the ads kills me. I have switched to web browser + reading mode. Also why can’t i read it offline?? I have a subscription.
analyzed.author: bot ot
analyzed.summary: User finds the app's ad formatting disruptive and uncomfortable for reading, prefers web browser reading mode, and is frustrated by the lack of offline reading despite having a subscription.

analyzed.title: Great read
analyzed.text: The journalism at the Atlantic is concise, fact driven and superbly written. It is my news source that I reach for when I am overwhelmed by the sheer volume of BS out in the world.
analyzed.author: Brewsbrother15
analyzed.summary: The user highly praises the Atlantic for its concise, fact-driven, and well-written journalism, considering it a reliable news source.

analyzed.title: Beautiful writing
analyzed.text: It’s like a breath of fresh air.  Thanks for all that your writers do.
analyzed.author: klramaman
analyzed.summary: The user expresses gratitude and appreciation for the writers, indicating a positive experience.

analyzed.title: Fair, Objective, Intelligent
analyzed.text: After a year of reading and listening, I am confident in describing The Atlantic as fair, objective and intelligent.  Their op-eds are full of facts and use logical deductions.
analyzed.author: unclekybo
analyzed.summary: The user praises The Atlantic for being fair, objective, and intelligent, highlighting the factual and logical nature of its op-eds.

analyzed.title: We will all miss the Reiners except the President
analyzed.text: Brilliant
analyzed.author: Tony on Iowa
analyzed.summary: The user expresses strong positive feedback with the word 'Brilliant'.

analyzed.title: *Update; once again I’m paying but my account disappeared. Hard to find any way to communicate.
analyzed.text:
What’s the point of the app. Today you ask me to subscribe to read my articles. WHY? Why do these apps frustrate and insult us when we’re subscribed and paid up?  Some dorky, we head that does not really understand people?  You’re not the only ones. This is more common perhaps there are fewer “normal people” supervising the techies who break what ain’t broke. What they don’t get is more often is that I often  cancel when this happens.  If I hasn’t read The Atlantic for 40 years I’d be gone.  I call it entropy by techies.
****************
Same as above but AI makes it worse. Seems to contradict The Atlantics values and tradition, treating me as a non-person.
analyzed.author: Bleeber
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated by forced subscription prompts despite being a paid subscriber, perceives poor tech design lacking human understanding, and feels AI integration worsens the experience, contradicting the app's values.

analyzed.title: Lags regularly, easier to just use website
analyzed.text: This app has been laggy for at least a year on my iPhone 13. Will regularly get stuck for 10+ seconds when trying to scroll through an article, on essentially every article. I’ve tried deleting and reinstalling several times. Very poor reading experience.
analyzed.author: nicknames are for kiddos
analyzed.summary: User experiences frequent lag and freezing when scrolling articles, leading to a poor reading experience despite reinstalling the app.

analyzed.title: David Brooks on Neoconservatism, Past and Future
analyzed.text: Just read this wonderful essay by David Brooks. I’m a fan going back quite some time; but, this is one of his very best. Historical context and analysis coupled with inspiring thoughts on a way forward post-Trump. I’m an economist and believe in the fundamental importance of private property rights. However, Brooks goes way beyond any sort of defense of capitalism - - and does so correctly in my view. “Character is destiny.”
analyzed.author: GeoShel
analyzed.summary: The reviewer highly praises David Brooks' essay for its historical context, inspiring analysis, and thoughtful perspective beyond capitalism.

analyzed.title: Great content, but buggy
analyzed.text: I love the articles, but the developer should improve navigation : the app hangs in various sections when going say from game to game.
analyzed.author: Tim_Chapel_Hill
analyzed.summary: User enjoys the articles but experiences app hangs when navigating between games, indicating navigation stability issues.

analyzed.title: Great content, glitchy app
analyzed.text: I really appreciate the articles included and the format is good. My issue is with the app performance, not the Atlantic Magazine. It routinely blacks out I. The middle of reading an article, leaving just the “home” arrow at the top. I like the games, but when you finish a game and want to choose another, the section blacks out and won’t reload. The only fix is to force quit the app and start over.
analyzed.author: Hilltopian Hiker
analyzed.summary: User appreciates content and format but experiences frequent app blackouts during article reading and after games, requiring force quit to recover.

analyzed.title: Objective, thoughtful, critical views
analyzed.text: Excellent, fearless, long-view perspective.  Excellent app.  Love the auto-read feature for all articles.
analyzed.author: An_MTE_Review
analyzed.summary: User praises the app's fearless, long-view perspective and appreciates the auto-read feature for all articles.

analyzed.title: Morning news.
analyzed.text: I’ve been listening as my morning news. Refreshing, a little bit less filtered than NPR.
analyzed.author: LarisaOOO
analyzed.summary: User appreciates the app as a morning news source, valuing its refreshing and less filtered content compared to NPR.

analyzed.title: More Than Ever
analyzed.text: Now more than ever we need the cogent analysis of writers and thinkers like Tom Nichols, David Frum, Jeffrey Goldberg, Anne Applebaum, the entire starry constellation of patriots who may yet offer help while we strive to save our country.
analyzed.author: Airborne Always
analyzed.summary: The review praises the insightful analysis provided by prominent writers and thinkers featured in the app.

analyzed.title: Intellectually honest and brave reporting. Great writing
analyzed.text:
Great writing with unusual
Range and wide range of interesting topics
analyzed.author: **kiankins**
analyzed.summary: The user appreciates the app's great writing and diverse range of interesting topics.

analyzed.title: Great content, terrible app
analyzed.text: I love The Atlantic. If I didn’t, I would have deleted this barely usable app ages ago. It is soooo slooooow to load anything. The games (which are excellent) are the worst offenders. I assume a good programmer could identify and fix the issues. With every app update I hope the slowness will be fixed. Alas, years later the app still coughs and chugs and displays a spinner (if I’m lucky. Sometimes it’s just blank)
analyzed.author: Info,RM
analyzed.summary: The user loves the content but is frustrated by the app's persistent slowness, especially in games, and frequent loading issues despite updates.

analyzed.title: Too many ads
analyzed.text: Seems like a $80 a year subscription is not enough for this mendacious app: they cram every single article with ads, and it's insufferable - to the point that I'm considering canceling my subscription altogether. Memo to The Atlantic: don't take your subscribers for suckers, thanks.
analyzed.author: Tumbuktu987654321
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated with excessive ads despite paying for a subscription and feels deceived by the app's practices.

analyzed.title: Can’t log in
analyzed.text: I have a subscription, I enter the email address and password, and it says: please enter your email address and password. Arrrrgggghhhh!
analyzed.author: Willy Mo222
analyzed.summary: User with a subscription is unable to log in despite entering credentials, facing repeated prompts to enter email and password.

analyzed.title: Why I Subscribe?
analyzed.text: The Atlantic ia a reader-supported periodical that is excellent at true journalism. It is well written and insightful about the world at large. I highly recommend it.
analyzed.author: DWR Review#1A
analyzed.summary: The reviewer highly praises The Atlantic for its true journalism, well-written content, and insightful coverage.

analyzed.title: Story text disappears while reading
analyzed.text: Love the content but for the past two weeks the story text disappears a minute into reading. Happens with every story. Even after exiting the story and restarting the app. Have redownloaded several times with the issue persisting. Restarted phone too. Also is happening on web app. As a paid subscriber, this is incredibly frustrating!
analyzed.author: Lkraffty
analyzed.summary: Paid subscriber experiences persistent issue where story text disappears shortly after starting, affecting both app and web versions despite multiple troubleshooting attempts.

analyzed.title: Underdeveloped
analyzed.text:
11/21/25: since two updates ago, the app blanks out while reading articles. The blank white screen becomes unresponsive and prevents article access.

~2023: The Atlantic Magazine is phenomenal, but the iPad app to deliver it is lacking. It is unstable and crashes frequently. It does not maintain the place in the article but jumps around with advertisements shifting the content, looses the article entirely when the app is closed. Finding articles is difficult, with the subpar search contributing to the frustration.
analyzed.author: Ek4532865fed
analyzed.summary: The app is unstable with frequent crashes, unresponsive blank screens, poor article navigation, and ineffective search functionality, severely impacting user experience.

analyzed.title: Great mag, app a work in progress
analyzed.text: When listening on AirPods, skipping backward does nothing, while skipping forward takes you to the next article in your queue—whether you’re finished or not. Skipping 90-second ads requires fishing your phone out of your pocket.
analyzed.author: Alexarond
analyzed.summary: User experiences issues with skip backward functionality and inconvenient ad skipping on AirPods.

analyzed.title: Refreshing. An oasis of  intelligent, long form journalism.  Make America Smart Again.
analyzed.text: Whether you agree of disagree with the clearly and elegantly presented ideas and coverage of current events and culture, The Atlantic is a bastion of intelligent long form journalism essential to thinking readers at a time when we need to Make American Smart Again.
analyzed.author: Super Kevlar
analyzed.summary: The review praises The Atlantic for its intelligent, well-presented long-form journalism and cultural coverage.

analyzed.title: Slow & glitchy
analyzed.text: The quality of the journalism is excellent, but this review is about the app. I’ve stopped trying to read articles in this app because, invariably, halfway through the article, the app will freeze, presumably while it loads the next ad for me to scroll past—and I’m a paid subscriber! I only use it for games now, which also load very slowly, and prefer to read articles in a browser instead.
analyzed.author: Choudofu
analyzed.summary: User experiences app freezes during article reading and slow game loading, leading to preference for browser reading despite being a paid subscriber.

analyzed.title: Ads galore
analyzed.text: Cannot believe the frequency of ads (even with a paid subscription) when listening to stories. A David Frum piece I was just listening to had ad interruptions every 2-3 minutes! Disgusting. Sincere regret on annual subscription.
analyzed.author: floor sitter
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated by frequent ad interruptions despite having a paid subscription, leading to regret over the annual subscription.

analyzed.title: Too many ads in paid subscription
analyzed.text: I can’t believe all the ads in my online subscription that I paid good money for! It is hard to read an article that is broken up by ads and this survey! So frustrating.
analyzed.author: jan-ie p
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated by ads and surveys interrupting content in a paid subscription, making it hard to read articles.

analyzed.title: The Rule of Law must stand!
analyzed.text:
Thank you Atlantic! My spirits were lifted this morning as I read the article by Judge Wolf! 
How powerful can one person be? We are a country of laws. 
Today is the time to act on that idea! Judge Wolf tells us simply his plight and his dedication to the RULE OF LAW! 
We cannot be silent! 
I am convinced the power of WE the People can be tidal way of freedom. 
Our elections in 2026 give us the opportunity to unite and speak loudly about our sinking democracy! A tsunami must come! People, young and old, must vote and defend voting rights! 
I talk to everyone about my concerns for our freedom and the democracy that we must defend at all costs. 
Thank you Judge Wolf.
analyzed.author: lynn sf
analyzed.summary: The user expresses strong appreciation for Judge Wolf's article and emphasizes the importance of defending democracy and voting rights.

analyzed.title: App freezes constantly
analyzed.text: Love the content, love supporting journalism. Hate the app. It freezes constantly, making reading a tedious chore of waiting for the app to allow me to continue scrolling. Even worse, it sometimes goes black and all the text disappears. Very disappointing and dis functional. 1/5 because of issues with the app.
analyzed.author: Biggityzzars
analyzed.summary: User loves the content but finds the app frequently freezes and sometimes goes black, causing a poor reading experience.

analyzed.title: They still haven’t fixed it
analyzed.text: Every month we go through the same thing. It can’t manage to figure out that I’m a subscriber. “Restore purchase” never works. This is the only app I pay money for that needs to be deleted and re-installed every month.
analyzed.author: Gnf222356789
analyzed.summary: The app fails to recognize active subscriptions and restore purchases, forcing users to reinstall monthly.

analyzed.title: Excellent
analyzed.text: I’ve had the subscription for one day, and I cannot stop reading this publication — the latest articles and older articles. The writing is engaging.
analyzed.author: The Renette
analyzed.summary: The user is highly engaged and satisfied with the publication's content and writing quality.

analyzed.title: Great content. Bad app
analyzed.text:
I love the journalism of the Atlantic but the app is pretty bad. First of all, to view articles you have to be a paid subscriber, if I’m paying I don’t want to see ads. Either offer two tier of subscriptions, a cheaper one with ads and a more expensive one without, or get rid of them entirely. 

The ads also aren’t incorporated into the app well. The content loads before the ads so you’ll begin reading and then the ads will finish loading and will scroll your view. Very annoying. 

But most annoying of all, 75% of the time I enter an article, the content will disappear from the page after around 10 seconds of being in the article. The only thing to do is leave the article and reenter. Though most of the time it will only disappear again requiring you to repeat the process.
analyzed.author: D$oney!
analyzed.summary: User is frustrated with mandatory subscription ads, poor ad integration disrupting reading, and frequent disappearance of article content requiring reentry.

analyzed.title: Excellent articles
analyzed.text: I discovered the Atlantic from seeing articles on Instagram. I enjoyed them so much, I subscribed to the magazine and always seem to find something very interesting and fulfilling to read.
analyzed.author: Roeroe68
analyzed.summary: User discovered the Atlantic via Instagram articles and finds the content interesting and fulfilling, leading to a subscription.

analyzed.title: Has declined in quality
analyzed.text: When too many articles begin to sound like the tripe found in The Guardian, it’s time to cancel the subscription. It’s sad because the thoughtful content is overwhelmed by polemical drivel that is too much like the inanities of The Guardian.
analyzed.author: croissants27
analyzed.summary: User is dissatisfied with the decline in content quality, citing an overabundance of polemical articles similar to The Guardian, leading to consideration of subscription cancellation.

analyzed.title: Love the audio choice
analyzed.text: Always excellent well researched articles. Audio with NOA saving my eyes.
analyzed.author: JewelWharton
analyzed.summary: The user praises the app for its excellent, well-researched articles and appreciates the audio feature for reducing eye strain.

analyzed.title: Great magazine.
analyzed.text: Have been subscribing to it for almost 15 years now.  I always look forward to the new copy.  I also made my wife a convert
analyzed.author: lfx1986
analyzed.summary: Long-term subscriber expresses strong satisfaction and enthusiasm for the product, also influencing others positively.

analyzed.title: The Atlantic
analyzed.text: Excellence in journalism
analyzed.author: We will survive this
analyzed.summary: The user praises the app for its excellent journalism.

analyzed.title: A Magazine For Our Times
analyzed.text: The articles featured in the Atlantic are very timely and thought provoking during these troubling times. I especially like Anne Applebaum featured articles.
analyzed.author: Joe Perogi
analyzed.summary: The user appreciates the timely and thought-provoking articles, particularly those by Anne Applebaum.

analyzed.title: Can’t stop reading!
analyzed.text: I cannot put this magazine down.  I virtually read it cover to cover.  Some of the best journalism I have ever read.  This magazine has shown me that I can still rely on unbiased articles informing me and making me a little more enlightened on what is happening in our country.
analyzed.author: Falls67
analyzed.summary: The user highly praises the magazine for its unbiased journalism and engaging content.

analyzed.title: Deep insights for current issues
analyzed.text: Facts with examples & explanations.  Opinions too but always differences very clear.  Awesome reporting that readers endorse either their subscriptions.
analyzed.author: $$$$the mag
analyzed.summary: The review praises the app for clear facts, examples, explanations, and distinct opinions, highlighting excellent reporting that encourages subscriptions.

analyzed.title: Complicit, corrupt coverage
analyzed.text:
I once loved this magazine, but it has strayed far from its abolitionist roots. When the "Israel Gaza Conflict" is reported on, this sorry excuse for a magazine unapologetically declares that 40,000 Palestinian lives are worth less than 4 Israeli hostages. And it continues to situate the colonial project of the Israeli state as the victim when every single reputable Human Rights organization has declared it a genocide (including those based in Israel). The NYT used to provide a "both sides" perspective on the lynching of Black Americans in 20th century, The Atlantic has shamelessly carried this abominable torch into the 21st century.

And this is just a single issue; the money they make from their obvious duplicity must be truly extraordinary.

This entire publication disgusts me. I am a high school social studies teacher and this publication is everything that is wrong with this world. It is an insult to the very idea of journalism and humanity. It may not be in this lifetime, but these cowards will one day be known for their evil.
analyzed.author: mattygeebs
analyzed.summary: The reviewer criticizes the magazine for biased and insensitive reporting, accusing it of lacking journalistic integrity and misrepresenting serious conflicts.

analyzed.title: Brilliance!
analyzed.text: Concise! Engaging!
analyzed.author: brooksmahogany
analyzed.summary: The user finds the app concise and engaging, indicating a positive experience.

analyzed.title: Barely an app
analyzed.text:
Not commenting on the journalism, this is an app review. 
This app could be so much better, right now it’s barely better than the website. Atlantic links don’t automatically open in the app. There’s no “read later” button for article links within the app that are shown throughout the article you’re reading so they just get lost. There are ads throughout every article even though only paying subscribers are able to read them. This is basic stuff that any decent subscription-based news/reading app should offer. 
I’d also like to be able to follow authors to be notified when they have new pieces available but considering the state of the app we’re not even close to little extras like that. I love reading the Atlantic — please make this app better, it would be so easy.
analyzed.author: SwaddlerRov
analyzed.summary: The app lacks basic features like in-app link opening, a read later button, and author follow notifications, and displays ads despite subscription, making it barely better than the website.

analyzed.title: A widget would be nice
analyzed.text: A widget with latest/top articles would be nice, similar to the NYT one
analyzed.author: gmconte
analyzed.summary: User requests a widget displaying latest or top articles similar to the NYT app.

analyzed.title: Substance > entertainment
analyzed.text: The articles and quality of writing are more rewarding than a scroll through social media. It’s part of my daily routine to peruse topics of interest and current events. App is user friendly and free from excessive noise. Ad-free version is well worth it.
analyzed.author: Evans651
analyzed.summary: User appreciates the high-quality articles, user-friendly interface, and ad-free experience, making the app a valuable part of their daily routine.

analyzed.title: Its official:  The Atlantic is life support
analyzed.text: As my curating and culling of my ever-sophisticating and siloing of subscriptions has become a way of life (i.e., “wellness” + a harem of specialists for each organ, joint, phalange and stage of life), I could name names but today, the one I cannot live without is The Atlantic.
analyzed.author: JimmyChooBoots
analyzed.summary: The user highly values The Atlantic subscription, considering it indispensable among their curated subscriptions.

reviews.title: Accessibility and Login Issues
reviews.text: Continue to have login issues, issues recognizing subscription, font is tiny. Access to the digital subscription is really hit or miss. As one reviewer pointed out, at least I don’t have to search for my subscriber number!
reviews.author: ElroyandJudy

reviews.title: TLS great; accessibility mediocre.
reviews.text: Not just clunky navigation — but print on ipad unnecessarily tiny and not adjustable.   Their writers deserve better
reviews.author: Mikesho

analyzed.title: Accessibility and Login Issues
analyzed.text: Continue to have login issues, issues recognizing subscription, font is tiny. Access to the digital subscription is really hit or miss. As one reviewer pointed out, at least I don’t have to search for my subscriber number!
analyzed.author: ElroyandJudy
analyzed.summary: User experiences persistent login problems, subscription recognition failures, tiny font size, and unreliable access to the digital subscription.

analyzed.title: TLS great; accessibility mediocre.
analyzed.text: Not just clunky navigation — but print on ipad unnecessarily tiny and not adjustable.   Their writers deserve better
